config_defs.name: database.hostname
config_defs.group: How should we connect to your database?
config_defs.documentation: IP address or hostname of the Oracle database server.

metadata.group_name: How should we connect to your database?

config_defs.name: database.port
config_defs.group: How should we connect to your database?
config_defs.documentation: Port number of the Oracle database server.

metadata.group_name: How should we connect to your database?

config_defs.name: database.user
config_defs.group: How should we connect to your database?
config_defs.documentation: Name of the Oracle database user to use when connecting to the database.

metadata.group_name: How should we connect to your database?

config_defs.name: database.password
config_defs.group: How should we connect to your database?
config_defs.documentation: Password of the Oracle database user to use when connecting to the database.

metadata.group_name: How should we connect to your database?

config_defs.name: database.dbname
config_defs.group: How should we connect to your database?
config_defs.documentation: Name of the database to connect to. In a multitenant container database, this is the name of the container database (CDB).

metadata.group_name: How should we connect to your database?

config_defs.name: database.service.name
config_defs.group: How should we connect to your database?
config_defs.documentation: Name of the database service to which to connect. In a multitenant container database, this is the service used to connect to the container database (CDB). For Oracle Real Application Clusters (RAC), use the service created by Oracle XStream.

metadata.group_name: How should we connect to your database?

config_defs.name: database.pdb.name
config_defs.group: How should we connect to your database?
config_defs.documentation: Name of the pluggable database to connect to in a multitenant architecture. The container database (CDB) name must be given via ``database.dbname`` in this case. This configuration should not be specified when connecting to a non-container database.

metadata.group_name: How should we connect to your database?

config_defs.name: database.out.server.name
config_defs.group: How should we connect to your database?
config_defs.documentation: Name of the XStream outbound server to connect to.

metadata.group_name: How should we connect to your database?

config_defs.name: database.tls.mode
config_defs.group: How should we connect to your database?
config_defs.documentation:
Specifies whether to use Transport Layer Security (TLS) to connect to the Oracle database. Select one of the following options: 
`disable` (default): Does not use a TLS connection.
`one-way`: Uses a TLS encrypted connection and also verifies the server's TLS certificate against the configured Certificate Authority (CA) certificates.

metadata.group_name: How should we connect to your database?

config_defs.name: database.processor.licenses
config_defs.group: How should we connect to your database?
config_defs.display_name: Total number of Oracle processors to license
config_defs.documentation: Specifies the number of Oracle processor licenses required for the source database server or cluster. The is determined by multiplying the total number of processor cores by a core processor licensing factor, as specified in the Oracle Processor Core Factor Table.

metadata.group_name: How should we connect to your database?

config_defs.name: output.key.format
config_defs.documentation: Sets the output Kafka record key format. Valid entries are AVRO, JSON_SR, or PROTOBUF. Note that you need to have Confluent Cloud Schema Registry configured when using a schema-based message format like AVRO, JSON_SR, and PROTOBUF.

config_defs.name: output.data.format
config_defs.documentation: Sets the output Kafka record value format. Valid entries are AVRO, JSON_SR, or PROTOBUF. Note that you need to have Confluent Cloud Schema Registry configured when using a schema-based message format like AVRO, JSON_SR, and PROTOBUF.

config_defs.name: topic.prefix
config_defs.group: How should we name your topic(s)?
config_defs.documentation:
Topic prefix that provides a namespace for the Oracle database server or cluster from which the connector captures changes. The topic prefix should be unique across all other connectors, since it is used as a prefix for all Kafka topic names that receive events from this connector. Only alphanumeric characters, hyphens, dots and underscores are accepted. 
Warning: Do not change the value of this property. If you change the value, after a restart, instead of continuing to emit events to the original topics, the connector emits subsequent events to topics whose names are based on the new value. The connector is also unable to recover its database schema history topic.

metadata.group_name: How should we name your topic(s)?

config_defs.name: table.include.list
config_defs.documentation: An optional, comma-separated list of regular expressions that match fully-qualified table identifiers for the tables whose changes you want to capture. When this property is set, the connector will only capture changes from the specified tables. Each identifier is of the form `schemaName.tableName`. By default, the connector captures changes from all non-system tables in each captured database. To match the name of a table, the connector applies the regular expression that you specify as an anchored regular expression. That is, the specified expression is matched against the entire identifier for the table; it does not match substrings that might be present in a table name. If you include this property in the configuration, do not set the ``table.exclude.list`` property.

config_defs.name: table.exclude.list
config_defs.documentation: An optional, comma-separated list of regular expressions that match fully-qualified table identifiers for the tables whose changes you do not want to capture. When this property is set, the connector captures changes from any table that is not specified in the exclude list. Each identifier is of the form `schemaName.tableName`. To match the name of a table, the connector applies the regular expression that you specify as an anchored regular expression. That is, the specified expression is matched against the entire identifier for the table; it does not match substrings that might be present in a table name. If you include this property in the configuration, do not set the ``table.include.list`` property.

config_defs.name: snapshot.mode
config_defs.documentation:
The criteria for running a snapshot upon startup of the connector. Select one of the following snapshot options: 
`initial` (default): The snapshot includes both the structure (schema) and data of the captured tables. Specify this value to populate topics with a complete representation of the data from the captured tables. After the snapshot completes, the connector begins to stream event records for subsequent database changes. 
`no_data`: The snapshot includes only the structure (schema) of captured tables. Specify this value if you want the connector to capture data only for changes that occur after the snapshot. After the snapshot completes, the connector begins to stream event records for subsequent database changes. 
`recovery`: Set this option to restore a database schema history topic that is lost or corrupted. After a restart, the connector runs a snapshot that rebuilds the topic from the source tables. You can also set the property to periodically prune a database schema history topic that experiences unexpected growth. WARNING: Do not use this mode to perform a snapshot if schema changes were committed to the database after the last connector shutdown.

config_defs.name: schema.history.internal.skip.unparseable.ddl
config_defs.documentation: A boolean value that specifies whether the connector should ignore a DDL statement that cannot be parsed or stop processing for a human to address the issue. The safe default is `false` which causes the connector to fail when it encounters an unparseable DDL statement. Setting the value to `true` should be done with care as it will cause the connector to skip processing any DDL statement it cannot parse, and this could potentially lead to schema mismatches and data loss.

config_defs.name: snapshot.database.errors.max.retries
config_defs.display_name: Max retries on snapshot database errors
config_defs.documentation: Specifies the number of retry attempts the connector will make to snapshot a table if a database error occurs. This configuration property currently only retries failures related to ORA-01466 error. By default, no retries are attempted.

config_defs.name: tombstones.on.delete
config_defs.documentation:
Controls whether a delete event is followed by a tombstone event. The following values are possible: 
`true`: For each delete operation, the connector emits a delete event and a subsequent tombstone event. 
`false`: For each delete operation, the connector emits only a delete event. 
After a source record is deleted, a tombstone event (the default behavior) enables Kafka to completely delete all events that share the key of the deleted row in topics that have log compaction enabled.

config_defs.name: skipped.operations
config_defs.documentation: A comma-separated list of operations to skip during streaming. You can configure the connector to skip the following types of operations: c (inserts/create), u (updates), d (deletes), t (truncates), and none to indicate nothing is skipped. The default value is t, ensuring that only truncate operations are skipped.

config_defs.name: schema.name.adjustment.mode
config_defs.documentation:
Specifies how schema names should be adjusted for compatibility with the message converter used by the connector. The following values are possible:  
`none` (the default) does not apply any adjustment. 
`avro` replaces the characters that cannot be used in the Avro type name with underscore. 
`avro_unicode` replaces the underscore or characters that cannot be used in the Avro type name with corresponding unicode like _uxxxx. Note: _ is an escape sequence like backslash in Java.

config_defs.name: field.name.adjustment.mode
config_defs.documentation:
Specifies how field names should be adjusted for compatibility with the message converter used by the connector. The following values are possible: 
`none` (the default) does not apply any adjustment. 
`avro` replaces the characters that cannot be used in the Avro type name with underscore. 
`avro_unicode` replaces the underscore or characters that cannot be used in the Avro type name with corresponding unicode like _uxxxx. Note: _ is an escape sequence like backslash in Java.

config_defs.name: heartbeat.interval.ms
config_defs.documentation: Controls how often the connector sends heartbeat messages to a heartbeat topic. It is useful in situations when no changes occur in the captured tables for an extended period. In such cases, there are no change event messages generated, causing the committed source offset to remain unchanged. As a result, the connector is unable to update the processed low watermark on the outbound server which could result in the database retaining archived redo log files longer than needed. The default value is 0 which disables the heartbeat mechanism.

config_defs.name: database.os.timezone
config_defs.documentation: Specifies the database server's operating system timezone. This is used to read the time when the LCR was generated at the source database. The default timezone is UTC. The value has to be a valid `java.time.ZoneId` identifier.

config_defs.name: decimal.handling.mode
config_defs.group: How should we handle data types?
config_defs.documentation:
Specifies how the connector should handle NUMBER, DECIMAL and NUMERIC columns. You can set one of the following options: 
`precise` (the default): Uses `java.math.BigDecimal` to represent values, which are encoded in the change events using a binary representation and Kafka Connect's `org.apache.kafka.connect.data.Decimal` type. Depending on the precision and scale, the most appropriate Kafka Connect integer type is used for integral values, ensuring that the value is represented without any loss of precision. 
`string`: Encodes values as formatted strings. Using the `string` option is easier to consume, but results in a loss of semantic information about the real type. 
`double`: Represents values using Java's `double`. Using `double` values is easier, but can result in a loss of precision.

metadata.group_name: How should we handle data types?

config_defs.name: time.precision.mode
config_defs.group: How should we handle data types?
config_defs.documentation:
Specifies how the connector should handle time, date, and timestamp columns. You can set one of the following options: 
`adaptive` (the default): Bases the precision of time, date, and timestamp values on the database column's precision. 
`connect`: always represents time, date, and timestamp values using Kafka Connect's built-in representations for Time, Date, and Timestamp, which uses millisecond precision regardless of the database columns' precision.

metadata.group_name: How should we handle data types?

config_defs.name: tasks.max
config_defs.group: Number of tasks for this connector
config_defs.documentation: Specifies the maximum number of tasks for the connector. Since this connector supports only a single task, the maximum is capped at 1.

config_defs.name: connector.class
config_defs.group: How should we connect to your data?

config_defs.name: name
config_defs.group: How should we connect to your data?
config_defs.documentation: Sets a name for your connector.

config_defs.name: tasks.max
config_defs.group: Number of tasks for this connector
config_defs.documentation: Maximum number of tasks for the connector.

config_defs.name: kafka.auth.mode
config_defs.documentation: Kafka Authentication mode. It can be one of KAFKA_API_KEY or SERVICE_ACCOUNT. It defaults to KAFKA_API_KEY mode.

config_defs.name: kafka.api.key
config_defs.documentation: Kafka API Key. Required when kafka.auth.mode==KAFKA_API_KEY.

connector_configs.name: confluent.topic.bootstrap.servers
connector_configs.value: Placeholder value to pass connector validations

config_defs.name: kafka.service.account.id
config_defs.documentation: The Service Account that will be used to generate the API keys to communicate with Kafka Cluster.

config_defs.name: kafka.api.secret
config_defs.documentation: Secret associated with Kafka API key. Required when kafka.auth.mode==KAFKA_API_KEY.

config_defs.name: datapreview.schemas.enable
config_defs.display_name: Show schemas in data preview request output
config_defs.documentation:
This config key only applies to data preview requests and governs whether the data preview output has record schema with it.
The visibility condition is set such that it can never be true.
So this key does not show in create connector UI.

config_defs.name: errors.tolerance
config_defs.documentation: Use this property if you would like to configure the connector's error handling behavior. WARNING: This property should be used with CAUTION for SOURCE CONNECTORS as it may lead to dataloss. If you set this property to 'all', the connector will not fail on errant records, but will instead log them (and send to DLQ for Sink Connectors) and continue processing. If you set this property to 'none', the connector task will fail on errant records.

config_defs.name: producer.override.linger.ms
config_defs.documentation: The producer groups together any records that arrive in between request transmissions into a single batched request. More details can be found in the documentation: https://docs.confluent.io/platform/current/installation/configuration/producer-configs.html#linger-ms.

config_defs.name: schema.context.name
config_defs.documentation: Add a schema context name. A schema context represents an independent scope in Schema Registry. It is a separate sub-schema tied to topics in different Kafka clusters that share the same Schema Registry instance. If not used, the connector uses the default schema configured for Schema Registry in your Confluent Cloud environment.

config_defs.name: auto.restart.on.user.error
config_defs.documentation: Enable connector to automatically restart on user-actionable errors.

config_defs.name: value.converter.enhanced.avro.schema.support
config_defs.documentation: Enable enhanced schema support to preserve package information and Enums. Applicable for Avro Converters.

config_defs.name: value.converter.connect.meta.data
config_defs.documentation: Allow the Connect converter to add its metadata to the output schema. Applicable for Avro Converters.

config_defs.name: value.converter.enhanced.protobuf.schema.support
config_defs.documentation: Enable enhanced schema support to preserve package information. Applicable for Protobuf Converters.

config_defs.name: value.converter.generate.index.for.unions
config_defs.documentation: Whether to generate an index suffix for unions. Applicable for Protobuf Converters.

config_defs.name: value.converter.int.for.enums
config_defs.documentation: Whether to represent enums as integers. Applicable for Protobuf Converters.

config_defs.name: value.converter.optional.for.nullables
config_defs.documentation: Whether nullable fields should be specified with an optional label. Applicable for Protobuf Converters.

config_defs.name: value.converter.generate.struct.for.nulls
config_defs.documentation: Whether to generate a struct variable for null values. Applicable for Protobuf Converters.

config_defs.name: value.converter.wrapper.for.nullables
config_defs.documentation: Whether nullable fields should use primitive wrapper messages. Applicable for Protobuf Converters.

config_defs.name: value.converter.wrapper.for.raw.primitives
config_defs.documentation: Whether a wrapper message should be interpreted as a raw primitive at root level. Applicable for Protobuf Converters.

config_defs.name: value.converter.object.additional.properties
config_defs.documentation: Whether to allow additional properties for object schemas. Applicable for JSON_SR Converters.

config_defs.name: value.converter.use.optional.for.nonrequired
config_defs.documentation: Whether to set non-required properties to be optional. Applicable for JSON_SR Converters.

config_defs.name: value.converter.decimal.format
config_defs.documentation:
Specify the JSON/JSON_SR serialization format for Connect DECIMAL logical type values with two allowed literals:
BASE64 to serialize DECIMAL logical types as base64 encoded binary data and
NUMERIC to serialize Connect DECIMAL logical type values in JSON/JSON_SR as a number representing the decimal value.

config_defs.name: value.converter.auto.register.schemas
config_defs.documentation: Specify if the Serializer should attempt to register the Schema.

config_defs.name: value.converter.use.latest.version
config_defs.documentation: Use latest version of schema in subject for serialization when auto.register.schemas is false.

config_defs.name: value.converter.latest.compatibility.strict
config_defs.documentation: Verify latest subject version is backward compatible when `use.latest.version` is `true`.

config_defs.name: key.converter.key.subject.name.strategy
config_defs.documentation: How to construct the subject name for key schema registration.

config_defs.name: value.converter.value.subject.name.strategy
config_defs.documentation: Determines how to construct the subject name under which the value schema is registered with Schema Registry.

config_defs.name: value.converter.reference.subject.name.strategy
config_defs.documentation: Set the subject reference name strategy for value. Valid entries are DefaultReferenceSubjectNameStrategy or QualifiedReferenceSubjectNameStrategy. Note that the subject reference name strategy can be selected only for PROTOBUF format with the default strategy being DefaultReferenceSubjectNameStrategy.

config_defs.name: value.converter.allow.optional.map.keys
config_defs.documentation: Allow optional string map key when converting from Connect Schema to Avro Schema. Applicable for Avro Converters.

config_defs.name: value.converter.flatten.singleton.unions
config_defs.documentation: Whether to flatten singleton unions. Applicable for Avro and JSON_SR Converters.

config_defs.name: value.converter.optional.for.proto2
config_defs.documentation: Whether proto2 optionals are supported. Applicable for Protobuf Converters.

config_defs.name: value.converter.flatten.unions
config_defs.documentation: Whether to flatten unions (oneofs). Applicable for Protobuf Converters.

config_defs.name: header.converter
config_defs.documentation: The converter class for the headers. This is used to serialize and deserialize the headers of the messages.
